t: Job 33
Wherefore,*p Job, I pray thee, hear my speeches, and hearken to all my words.
Behold,*p now I have opened my mouth, my tongue hath spoken in my mouth.
My*p words shall be of the uprightness of my heart: and my lips shall utter knowledge clearly.
The*p Spirit of God hath made me, and the breath of the Almighty hath given me life.
If*p thou canst answer me, set thy words in order before me, stand up.
Behold,*p I am according to thy wish in God's stead: I also am formed out of the clay.
Behold,*p my terror shall not make thee afraid, neither shall my hand be heavy upon thee.
Surely*p thou hast spoken in mine hearing, and I have heard the voice of thy words, saying,
I*p am clean without transgression, I am innocent; neither is there iniquity in me.
Behold,*p he findeth occasions against me, he counteth me for his enemy,
He*p putteth my feet in the stocks, he marketh all my paths.
Behold,*p in this thou art not just: I will answer thee, that God is greater than man.
Why*p dost thou strive against him? for he giveth not account of any of his matters.
For*p God speaketh once, yea twice, yet man perceiveth it not.
In*p a dream, in a vision of the night, when deep sleep falleth upon men, in slumberings upon the bed;
Then*p he openeth the ears of men, and sealeth their instruction,
That*p he may withdraw man from his purpose, and hide pride from man.
He*p keepeth back his soul from the pit, and his life from perishing by the sword.
He*p is chastened also with pain upon his bed, and the multitude of his bones with strong pain:
So*p that his life abhorreth bread, and his soul dainty meat.
His*p flesh is consumed away, that it cannot be seen; and his bones that were not seen stick out.
Yea,*p his soul draweth near unto the grave, and his life to the destroyers.
If*p there be a messenger with him, an interpreter, one among a thousand, to shew unto man his uprightness:
Then*p he is gracious unto him, and saith, Deliver him from going down to the pit: I have found a ransom.
His*p flesh shall be fresher than a child's: he shall return to the days of his youth:
He*p shall pray unto God, and he will be favourable unto him: and he shall see his face with joy: for he will render unto man his righteousness.
He*p looketh upon men, and if any say, I have sinned, and perverted that which was right, and it profited me not;
He*p will deliver his soul from going into the pit, and his life shall see the light.
Lo,*p all these things worketh God oftentimes with man,
To*p bring back his soul from the pit, to be enlightened with the light of the living.
Mark*p well, O Job, hearken unto me: hold thy peace, and I will speak.
If*p thou hast any thing to say, answer me: speak, for I desire to justify thee.
If*p not, hearken unto me: hold thy peace, and I shall teach thee wisdom.
